div.head: Description of Monument
div.p: White marble garland sarcophagus; for further description see Isik 138

div.head: Description of Text
div.p: On the tabella (l.1 on the upper moulding, parts of l.6 in the handles on either side). The text must have begun on the lid and was concluded on the lower moulding of the tabella and/or along the bottom edge of the chest.

div.head: Letters
div.p: Distinct from Aphrodisian norms, reasonably well designed, cut and aligned, probably third century. for sigma, W for omega, small omicron in ll.1, 6, 10, 12, 13; ligatured ΗΛ (l.3), ΗΜ (l.8), ΗΝ (l.6), ΝΕ (l.13), WΝ (ll.2, 10). Star for denarius; slanting stroke before the figure.

div.head: Date
div.p: Perhaps first half of the third century (lettering, spelling, nomenclature)

div.head: Translation
div.p: a. [? The sarcophagus belongs to male name and to female name] his wife, and their children, the Aurelii Artemidoros and Zosimos. No one else may be buried in the sarcophagus and if anyone buries anyone apart from those named he shall pay to the most eminent council of the People of Mastaura three thousand denarii. The copy of this inscription is filed in the [?city's archive - - -

div.head: Commentary
div.p: Since formulae as well as lettering are a little different from those of Aphrodisias, the text was clearly drafted and cut at Mastaura (in the foothills on the north side of the Maeander Valley, between Nysa and Antioch on the Maeander). The owning family had probably received Roman citizenship under the Edict of Caracalla in A.D. 212. Although their funerary fine is not a high one, they may have been a family of some local consequence since their tomb was under the protection of the city council.

p.rs: Neighbouring settlement, Mastaura, so not seen.

div.head: History of Recording
div.p: Recorded by F. Isik; read by Reynolds from the photograph.
